After listening to maiden speeches in this place, I think that is what I and a number of other people are committed to doing.

I remember my first trip to the Northern Territory. I had been there about a week and I took a team of doctors, leaders of various medical groups, out there. I must have met and spoken to over 500 Aboriginal people in the space of a week. I recall returning and speaking to the then Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, the Hon. Robert Tickner, a man whose ability never matched his sincerity. I said, `I think there's a problem with ATSIC. I have just spoken to, I think, some 500 Aboriginal people. I haven't met a single person who could say anything positive about ATSIC.' In fact, even ATSIC regional councillors were criticising ATSIC. Whilst there will always be critics of any organisation, particularly a semi-government body, you know you have a problem when that happens. The minister's response to me was, `Look, Brendan, this is what self-determination is all about. I am not responsible. It's ATSIC's responsibility.' Therein lies the problem.

When Graham Richardson was the health minister, he went to the Kimberleys with
60 Minutes
. He gave us another glimpse of the problem when he was asked by Charles Woolley why, after 11 years in government, the situation was still so bad. He said, `I've spent a lifetime reading polls, and concern for Aboriginal people is not in the top million issues worrying the voters.' The problem is that when the buck does not stop with the minister, no matter how well‐intentioned our efforts may be, very little happens.

I subscribe to a Jesuit publication called
Eureka Street
. One of the correspondents to that publication is Jack Waterford, who is the editor of the
Canberra Times
. In the May edition, in editorialising about Aboriginal affairs under the new government, he said:
The misdiagnosis—
that is, in relation to ATSIC—

meant that an unwieldy, undemocratic and unworkable political structure was created. It was not permitted or encouraged to devise integrated plans for communities or families. Both the political and the administrative structures found themselves
standing on functional mountains, giving out money for specific purposes to scads of incorporated bodies, themselves both short on administrative expertise and having problems of accounting to their own constituencies. The glory of ATSIC, from Labor's point of view, was that when anything was wrong in an Aboriginal community, the minister could shake his head and explain it was not his fault. The priorities were set by ATSIC and they divvied up the cake. It was usually done with such skill that no‐one ever looked at the size of the cake. It was different once. As Ian Viner or Fred Chaney or Peter Baume could attest, there was a time when a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was under personal assault for each and every problem that was uncovered. Wittingly or not, John Herron and John Howard may have restored this situation.

This bill changes the nature of regional councils; it reduces their size; it makes open to public scrutiny meetings and documents. It empowers the Australian Electoral Commission to have more authority over the way in which elections are held. It also provides for the power to appoint an administrator. But in order for that to be done the minister has to be satisfied that the administration of the commission and of its money have involved fraud or gross mismanagement.

Speakers on the other side of the chamber are no less or more well intentioned than those on this side. But what they have failed to recognise—and what I think the previous minister failed to recognise—is that there has been a change in mood in the Australian community generally. There is now finally—perhaps, in some small way, due to the efforts of Graham Richardson and others—a higher political priority placed on both the problems and the progress. With these rising expectations has come a significant degree of frustration. The worst thing that any government—whether it be our government or the Keating government, had it won the election—could have done for indigenous Australians would have been to have allowed it to continue.

The support that the member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) achieved—despite the member having views to which I take strong exception—is a signal and a message that we ignore at our own peril; that is, that people had just about had enough. The member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) is quite right in saying that this approach is not the solution
to Aboriginal problems, and none of us on this side are foolish enough to think that it is. But it is a move in the right direction. If we don't have political support behind us, this parliament may well have significantly more people who hold the same views as those held by the member for Oxley. In my opinion, such people would not be interested in seeing significant positive changes made in this area.

There are many other things that I would like to say. I visited one community—I will not name it—in the Top End where things were terrible. There were 43 people living in a three‐bedroom house with one toilet. There were many people without housing. The member for Kalgoorlie looks after many similar communities. I said to the president of the community, `Was it always like this?' He replied, `No, we used to have a market garden. We used to have dwellings that were respectable and health was generally pretty good.' I said, `What happened?' He replied, `It all stopped when Gough Whitlam started sending what we call sit down money.' Therein lies another essential message—this is not the solution in itself to indigenous problems—that, whatever we do, we have to do everything we can to help people to help themselves.
In concluding, I would like to read one of the recommendations from the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody:

The third prerequisite of the empowerment of Aboriginal people in their communities is having a place, an established method, a procedure whereby the broader society can supply the assistance referred to and the Aboriginal society can receive it whilst, at the same time, maintaining its independent status and without a welfare dependent position being established as between the two groups. This requires an adherence to the principles of self‐determination.
These are not things that we are interfering with this legislation. Also pertinent to this bill is:

That ATSIC councillors and commissioners at an early stage be encouraged to consult with Aboriginal organisations and communities to develop a program for training staff of Aboriginal organisations and communities in appropriate management and accounting procedures to ensure the efficiency and integrity of the organisations which are cultur
ally appropriate. In particular, there should be a commitment to devising management procedures which provide rules for the relationship obligations and rights—both individually and as between each other—of directors, managers and staff of Aboriginal organisations.

talk.start.para: —in reply—In the very short time left for the debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill, I would like to try to draw a few things together. I apologise to the opposition for the difficulty in the timing of this. We had been in opposition for 8½ years, and the last day of the sitting timetable is often very difficult. I do not think that we can take all the blame for that.

speech.para: I would like to acknowledge the contributions by the speakers in this debate. I am sorry I was not able to be present in the House, but I was able to catch much of what many people said. I particularly acknowledge the contribution of the member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), who is still in the chamber. If we had been able to have more of those types of speeches by members on both sides of the House in the last 10 or 15 years, we might have done a bit more.

I also acknowledge the contribution of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), whom, in terms of representation and practical, on‐the‐ground experience, you cannot ignore; nor can you doubt his commitment. Even if you do not agree with what he says, his commitment is unquestionable. One thing I should pick up on is his talk of guilt.

I actually do not think guilt is what drives a lot of people. I think it is a frustration and a desire to see something get better and hope that what we will do will make things better. But there is the frustration that they do not seem to be improving much. The debate tonight shows the difficulty in this area; there were a whole range of opinions expressed by those on all sides of the House and there was a bit of truth in all of them.

When I became shadow minister in 1990 I was told by a former minister, Fred Chaney, that the job would change me. It certainly did, and that is what the former minister and I share from different sides of the House.

speech.speaker: Price, Roger, MP

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to speak on this bill and I welcome all the members of the public who have gathered here this morning to hear my contribution on this bill. I want to say at the outset that, if the former government had introduced a bill with the purposes of this bill, that is, having first attempted to remove a board, introducing a bill to increase the number of board members, we would have been subject to a great deal of criticism, if not outrage, about our tactics. But this is precisely what the bill proposes to do.

speech.para: I have suggested that there is a degree of double standards in this bill, but the opposition is not going to oppose it, Mr Deputy Speaker. You might ask why not. Basically, the issue of air safety is such a serious one that no party, whether in government or in opposition, would wish to be held accountable for the obstruction of a change process, which at some point or another may lead to a calamity. So, in a sense, as is usual in government, it is on the head of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, to accept responsibility for these changes.

In the amendment moved by my colleague the shadow minister, the member for Melbourne, Lindsay Tanner, we specifically say that no person should be appointed to the board who has engaged recently in political lobbying or public advocacy on aviation safety issues on behalf of any company or interest group involved in the aviation industry. Frankly, that section of the amendment could be described as the `get Dick Smith amendment'. I do not believe this is moved by personal animus but rather that someone who has taken such a high profile and partisan approach to air safety should not be part of the minister's endeavours to increase the board.

I know of a couple of the members of the existing board. Bill Fisher is the head of the Industrial Relations Commission in New South Wales. I have had the pleasure of meeting Gabi Hollows in my electorate and I think she is a first‐class person to be a consumer advocate. I think it is important that we have a consumer representative. Of course, we have two other
members with specific expertise on the board in relation to air safety. Claire Pollock is a systems safety expert and Geoff Molloy is an ex‐pilot.

In my own electorate, issues of civil aviation and air safety are of some concern to my constituents. You may recall that the former government split the old civil aviation body into two. It structurally separated Airservices Australia, which, if you like, is the operating arm, from CASA, the safety arm. I think that that was a very good move, probably long overdue. We tend in government to set up boards and statutory authorities and sometimes corporations which we invest with a great deal of independence. We believe that they should get on and do their job impartially and that there should be some distance between those bodies and the minister.

But I have to say that politics these days, or society, does not allow us that luxury. Because no matter how much the particular organisation is independent, inevitably it is the minister who ends up wearing any untoward experiences. I could use a more colourful word. But I have observed, Mr Deputy Speaker—and I know other members have observed—your very strict standards and I will resist any temptation to use such a word in conjunction with fans! So what I am saying about this bill is that Minister Sharp firstly sought to get the resignations of board members and failed, and now is introducing this bill to increase the number of board members. I do not know that we approve of the approach he is adopting, but we are certainly not going to oppose it.

I mentioned that my constituents are very interested in matters of civil aviation. For example, during the last election there was quite some concern that Airservices Australia had failed to deliver the possible flight paths for Badgerys Creek airport. I think that failure, and other issues associated with Badgerys Creek, cost me and some of my colleagues dearly in the last election. I must say that whilst I am supporting the minister in relation to this bill—as the opposition is—I cannot say that I am supporting him in relation to other matters in his portfolio area having to do with civil aviation in my electorate.

For example, I find it really regrettable that, more than 100 days after the election, with more than 10 per cent of the government's time having expired before the next election is due, my constituents are no better informed about Badgerys Creek than they were before the election. We have yet to see any draft guidelines for the environmental impact statement, even though we extended the date for public submissions for those guidelines from 1 March to 1 April and they were due to be released in May. Here we are at the end of June and the draft guidelines have not been produced. We do not know what the public process of comment on those draft guidelines will be. We do not know the locations of public consultation about those draft guidelines.

Furthermore, in relation to civil aviation matters in my electorate, during the last election the then government had given a commitment to set up an advising committee—one comprised of experts, but also of locals—to sit between the EIS process and the ministers. We have had no announcement of a commitment by the new government to such a body, much less the names of the people who might serve on such a committee. As I reminded the minister on my way to the House, in a way the new government has the same problem as the old government. That is, the public have to have confidence in the EIS for Badgerys Creek.

We must have a rigorous EIS process so that whatever the outcome, whether it is in favour of the airport or opposed to it, people will accept the EIS verdict. I certainly want to be in that position. I am certainly interested in any suggestions that strengthen that process and
would give greater credibility to the outcome of that process. But as I said to the minister, `The delay is costing you.' As each day slips by and people are no better informed, it diminishes the chances that that process will be believed.

I have to say a couple of other things. It is true to say that almost every portfolio minister has reported in some way on the prospects of cuts in his portfolio area. In relation to transport and the environment, if we are to have a credible EIS process the government is going to have to invest some money in public consultation, informing people and allowing people to be satisfied that the process is fair and reasonable, and—even more than that—allowing them direct input into the process.

Public consultation delays things. Public consultation involves extra expenditure. I sincerely hope that, in relation to the EIS process, there will be no trying to save expenditure here. In saving money, the minister could very well be penny‐wise and pound‐foolish, as they say. On behalf of my constituents who, as I have said, are exhibiting a great deal of interest in civil aviation matters, I sincerely hope that the government will stop stonewalling on the EIS process, that it will commit to releasing the draft EIS, release the schedule of public consultation about the draft EIS and the rest of the EIS process, and also nominate the locations and the timings at which ordinary people in my electorate and in others affected by Badgerys Creek will be allowed to inform themselves and, in turn, have input into the process.

As I said, to a degree there are double standards about this bill. If we had tried to sack a board or get a board to resign when we were in government, we would be have been lampooned by the press and the public. If we had attempted to introduce legislation like this to expand the board and had specifically tried to target one member of the public who was a partisan to be a new member of that board—or, indeed, to be deputy chairman of that board—again, we would have been lampooned. As I mentioned earlier, civil aviation is a very serious issue. I do not believe that any party, particularly the Labor Party as the opposition, wishes to accept responsibility in any way for any adverse outcome that may, down the track, devolve as a result of this bill and the transport minister's decision.

speech.speaker: McLeay, Leo, MP

talk.start.para: —I support the amendment to the second reading motion on the Civil Aviation Amendment Bill 1996 which was moved by Mr Tanner, and I will say a few things on that matter. I will also speak about some general matters on the administration of civil aviation in this country, particularly as it relates to Sydney.

speech.para: I join with the member for Chifley (Mr Price) in what he has just said about the probity of the government in introducing this legislation. The absolutely outrageous pressure that the government has put on Mr Justice Fisher, who is the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, to resign has been unconscionable, in my view. The government seems to have taken the view that it should just politicise all these things. Mr Justice Fisher is a person of eminent standing and is the chief judge of the labour court in New South Wales. Before that, he was a very successful Queen's Counsel in Sydney. He is a man whose judgment is respected by all those who know him, and he is a person who is not engaged in partisan political activities, which are particularly precluded by his job as a judge.

This legislation is about the government wanting to sack Mr Justice Fisher and put one of their political stooges into this job: a fellow who spent a fortune putting out ads for the government in the last election campaign, and who is the discredited former chairman of the old board that ran civil aviation in this country for some years. He is the man who came forward with the discredited proposition of `affordable safety': Dick Smith. Dick Smith, whom
this bill is all about, is a fellow who has no credibility in this. He is a fellow who has spent a lot of time talking about how he is the voice of aviation.
He is the voice of people who want to fly helicopters around the suburbs, and he is the voice of small aircraft operators, but he is certainly not the voice of the travelling public. Indeed, the travelling public in Australia does not at all like the idea of affordable safety.

I am sure members of this parliament, along with the business community of Australia, probably spend the greatest proportion of time travelling in aeroplanes, and the thought that there is a concept such as affordable safety is a pretty terrifying one. But that is what Mr Smith's idea was: that we should let all these things rip. While Mr Smith was able to say that there were very few airline crashes when he was the chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, I think the difficulties we have had with air safety, with commuter operators, is a direct outgrowth of Mr Smith's discredited policy of affordable safety.

Mr Smith's argument was that we ought to let it rip; let small operators get out there and run their businesses. That ethos that filtered down in the civil aviation area and allowed for some of these more tragic occurrences in the commuter area is a direct result of the attitude that Dick Smith had when he was the supremo of the civil aviation area.

Members on the other side might say that he was an appointment of ours. Yes, he was an appointment of ours. We put him on the board and then we made him chairman. If you speak to Senator Collins, who was the minister at the time, he will tell you that it took him about 15 minutes after that to work out that Dick Smith was probably the worst chairman that we ever had. He made a number of entreaties to Mr Smith that he ought to resign and it is quite well known that the government of the day was not all that happy with Mr Smith as the chairman of that body. We did not bring in a bill to undermine him. We let him run his course and we never reappointed him. We did not bring in a bill to rearrange the board, to put someone in to look over Mr Smith's shoulder. If the government wants to do that to Justice Fisher, that is its prerogative, but it should not come in here with this sleazy tactic of expanding the board.

The government talks about jobs for the boys, for goodness sake! Dick Smith is a corporate member of the Liberal Party. This is a fellow who spent a lot of his own money in the last elections putting ads in the paper for the Liberal Party. You do not get much more commitment to a party than that, where someone actually shells out their own money for big ads in the paper. But the government says, `Dick Smith? Don't think we've heard of him. We've seen a bit of him in the paper; knows a lot about aviation.' Dick Smith knows far more about the Liberal Party than he knows about aviation. The government wants to go and corrupt this body by expanding it to put its political mates on it.

I think the second reading amendment being put forward by Mr Tanner is the one that ought to be followed if the government is serious in what it says it wants to do about the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. Mr Tanner's amendment states:
Whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that:

(1)
it is appropriate that the Board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority should include members in areas such as the law, regulation and general systems safety, as well as members with specific expertise in aviation . . .

Indeed, that is the way the board is constructed now. There are people who represent the travelling public, who probably ought to have a bit of a say in what happens with the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. There is a very eminent judge in Justice Fisher. There is a person
who has very significant experience in large jets as well as the small weekenders that Mr Smith has some expertise in. We think the board at present is a fairly well constituted board.
The important thing which is raised in the second paragraph of Mr Tanner's amendment is:

no person should be appointed to the Board who has engaged recently in political lobbying or public advocacy on aviation safety issues on behalf of any company or interest group involved in the aviation industry.

I suppose Mr Tanner is being quite generous there in not suggesting Mr Smith's other interest, which is the Liberal Party of Australia. I think the parliament should think very carefully about whether we want to have the discredited Dick Smith back on the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and whether we want the discredited Dick Smith running his old discredited line again of affordable safety.

There is no such thing as affordable safety. In Australia we have been very lucky in this area. There have been few significant aviation disasters. Some people would tell you that that is a function of the weather here and the lack of congestion in the airways as much as it is the work of the civil aviation bureaucracy. I think that what we want in that bureaucracy are people who are going to put safety to the forefront.

I also wish to say a few things about the way civil aviation has degenerated in the Sydney basin since the government came to office. We saw the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in the election campaign, for blatant political purposes, decide that they were going to let not 1,000 flowers bloom but 1,000 planes fly anywhere and everywhere that they wanted to over the Sydney basin. Then, the week after the election, we had revealed this deal that seems to have been done with some obscure group that wishes to promote an airport at Holsworthy. In all the competitions or considerations that have been held over the previous years as to where a second airport for Sydney should be built, Holsworthy had always come in second or third last. Now we have the government promoting it to being second best.

It raises interesting questions about what this airport might be like because Holsworthy is an area that has great amounts of unexploded ordnance on the site and it is also an area that has very deep ravines and river valleys. One of the reasons that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) gave as to why he thought Holsworthy should be given consideration and why he thought Badgerys Creek was not terrific was that there were rolling hills at Badgerys Creek.

We have gone from a situation where an airport site is given a downgrading in the minister's eyes because it has a rolling hills topography to one where a site that is full of ravines becomes popular all of a sudden. It just boggles the mind. I do not know; maybe the government has some new technology that will enable it to develop a machine that will explode all the unexploded bombs on the firing range there and which will blow all the dirt into the ravines so that with one big bang it will have flattened out the Holsworthy area. Unless the government has something like that in mind, then just the engineering task for turning Holsworthy into an airport is daunting, to say the least.

There is also the difficulty that it will cause to the residents who live around that Holsworthy area. They all went to the election reading about the big aircraft noise debate in Sydney and thinking, `Well, with all these maps that have been drawn, we are pretty safe. No‐one is talking about putting an airport in my backyard.' They then got rid of Bob Tickner because they were feeling pretty safe out there in those nice little new suburbs like Wattle Grove. Then the week
after the election they found there was a confidence trick—that the Prime Minister was not thinking about putting an airport out at Badgerys Creek; but there was this proposal for Holsworthy.

It turns out that these people had been to see the Prime Minister before the election. This is the Prime Minister who was going to bring honesty and probity back into the political system. But did we get one whisper of this during the election campaign? Not on your nelly, because they did not want the truth to get in the way of beating Bob Tickner in Hughes. We never heard the new member for Hughes, Danna Vale, saying anything about this during the election campaign—not a word. The people who bought houses out in Wattle Grove have just lost tens of thousands of dollars from the value of their houses. No‐one in their right mind would buy a house there now. The government has tainted that area for quite some time because of its proposals to allow those real estate sharks who are behind the Lawrence Hargraves project to come out there, hoping to build an airport at Holsworthy.

Also during the election campaign, we heard a few other mistruths told around the place. I remember reading in the
Sydney Morning Herald
that the Prime Minister was never going to let planes fly over the Lowe electorate. The people of Lowe had a choice: if they wanted no more aircraft noise, the simple choice was to vote for Mr Zammit; if they wanted aircraft noise, they should keep voting for Mrs Easson. If they wanted their property values to go up, they should vote for Zammit; if they wanted aircraft noise, they should vote for Easson. Unfortunately, the people of Lowe did vote for Mr Zammit. A great number of those people voted for Mr Zammit because they believed the Prime Minister when he said that there would not be planes flying over the electorate of Lowe under a Liberal Party government. They voted for him for that.

But what has happened since then? We have let the thousand aircraft fly. On Saturday last, the Federal Airports Corporation's inquiry unit received nearly 400 complaints about aircraft noise in Sydney. Most of those were complaints about northerly and westerly departures. On Sunday of last week, before 5 p.m. it had received nearly 300 complaints. There are new noise hot spots occurring around Sydney now. Suburbs such as Dulwich Hill, Summer Hill, Ashfield, Concord, Petersham, Lewisham, Earlwood, Arncliffe, Haberfield and Bexley never used to experience aircraft noise, but they are now getting it on a daily basis. Currently around Sydney there are no designated flight paths. Planes taking off to the north have only to fly four nautical miles before they can turn and fly wherever they like.

I have to tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not think many of those pilots or the people in the control tower heard what the Prime Minister said. I really do not think they did, because you have got a lot of planes flying over Haberfield, Croydon, Burwood and Strathfield in the electorate of Lowe. There are a lot of people complaining. I know, because my electorate is next‐door, and I get the complaints from them when they have rung Mr Zammit and he has given them a mealy‐mouthed explanation about not knowing that this was going to happen because John Howard said it would not happen. They ring my office and complain about these things.

So much for the promise made to the people of Lowe that there would be no more planes flying over Lowe, and so much for the lack of information given to the people of Wattle Grove when they concealed this idea to build an airport next to where they live. The government does not have very clean hands on this aircraft business in the Sydney basin. What we really need to see is the government, rather than just letting these planes fly everywhere, starting to give
some cogent view of what we should be doing with Sydney airport and with the air transportation needs of the city of Sydney.

The great worry that I have now is that we are going to see the EIS for Badgerys Creek fall over. There is no doubt in any way, shape or form that an EIS for Holsworthy will fall over. And, in six or eight months time, we will find ourselves with no alternative site for an airport in Sydney—no site. The government will think that is pretty good, because they will tip back into the general revenue fund the money that we allocated in the budget for work at Badgerys Creek and say, `We've taken $600 million off the bottom line—and it wasn't really our fault because the EIS fell down.' But, after 10 or 15 years of planning, we will not have a site.

We will be back to where Malcolm Fraser was when he got the report of the study on the major airport needs of Sydney. We will be back to Sydney airport, no other site, and absolute chaos for the people who live south of Sydney Harbour. The reality is that if you do not have an alternate site constructed shortly, Sydney airport will meet its capacity and you will have to do away with the curfew, you will have to do away with the cap of 80 movements an hour that the Labor government put on this airport, and you will also ensure that commuters who come from country New South Wales will not have any service into Sydney airport at all. They will have none because the government will sell these slots at the airport for landings and the pressure for the use of the airport from the major operators will keep country commuters out. What we will have in a few years time will be an impossible situation at Sydney airport.

So the government really needs to start to think about this seriously and not get themselves caught up in the politics of: `We think the Labor Party hurt us, so we are now going to hurt Labor voters.' They probably ought, in the first instance, to stop hurting the people who voted for them—the people in Lowe and out in Hughes. And they certainly should not put a discredited person such as Dick Smith on this board. They should leave the people on the board alone so that they can do the job they were appointed to do.

speech.speaker: Morris, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —The Civil Aviation Amendment Bill is a very small bill, with few words, but it is a bill of great significance. I have to say that, with all of my experience in relation to aviation matters and aviation safety matters, I am deeply concerned at what I see happening in aviation safety since the change in government. I fear for the minister, with whom I have a very good relationship and with whom I have worked very closely over a number of years. I will go through it as quickly as I can in the time I have available to me to set out the grounds for my fears at the course I see being undertaken.

speech.para: The bill itself, as introduced by the minister, simply expands the membership of the board. That is not a problem. A board can be any size you want it to be. I do not see any problem with that. The board could have been six, seven, nine, or whatever—that is not a problem. What concerns me is the manner in which it is being done. And what concerns me more than anything else is what is behind all of this.

I know that when we looked at the legislation last year that set up the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, the now minister was asking questions and—I did not realise it at the time—he was pressing for more information on the powers of the minister to sack members of the board. Page 43 of the
Hansard
transcript for 26 April last year shows that he said:

How can it be made more accountable to him if, at the end of the day, the minister may be able to dismiss people for noncompliance? I think it is a basic failure. If it is to be accountable, the minister must have the power to do what he ultimately feels is important, yet you are telling me he cannot quite do that.

And so it goes on—for those who want to look through it in
Hansard
. It worries me that this legislation is before us now and that those thoughts were in the minister's head at that time. It is very clear that, regardless of who the members of the board who were subsequently appointed were to be, he had in mind that, were there to be a change in government, he wanted to have the power to sack the board. That is not Morris's opinion; it is simply there in the transcript where it is set out.
When we also turn to his second reading speech, he says:
The addition of the Board of two extra members with aviation experience will increase aviation safety in Australia.

What experience? In the industry, the last person you want to put in to manage an airline operation is a pilot. Pilots are highly trained, highly specialised individuals operating a public conveyance—a piece of transport equipment. You show me an organisation in the world—a successful one—that has a pilot as the manager.

What you need on a board is a group of dispassionate people who are skilled in particular fields and who are able to assess the information brought forward from specialists in the field—and this is a highly technical field. You need people who are able to dispassionately look at the facts and information. Behind all this is not somebody's indulgence: this is about public safety, the most important area of public safety in this country. That is why I am so gravely concerned at what I see happening, and it is why I am concerned for the minister.

What kind of experience will there be? It is not detailed. The minister says that aviation is a complex and detailed industry that requires people to administer it who have `appropriate qualifications'. What qualifications? I refer to the words of the Chief Opposition Whip, the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), who has just left us. I will leave them unspoken. Go back and think about his words, `What qualifications?' The qualifications are unspoken, not spoken of in the
Hansard
last year in what was there. Can we be confident that, if it is to be on a mateship basis—and I will come to that in a moment, from another publication—who then accepts responsibility?

We have here the most critical area of public safety. We want people, as I said, who are dispassionate and skilled. Bill Fisher has to make judgments on all industrial relations matters in the state of New South Wales. He is not a plumber; he is not an electrician; he is not a clerk. He is a man skilled in his professional field. He chairs the Industrial Relations Commission in New South Wales. Yet it is said that he is unfit for this task and that he ought to go. By what principle? By what standard? By what qualification?

If you follow through on the idea that you only have those people making decisions about aviation who can fly aeroplanes, we should not have a Prime Minister, the government should not make any decisions, and no‐one in the cabinet should be dealing with aviation matters, because they are not pilots. The ludicrousness of that kind of argument! I want to see on the board decent, honest people who have good commonsense and are skilled in making decisions and are accountable: not mates. Can we be confident of cronies?
It is fortunate that Mr Boyd Munro is here. I am going to turn to his editorial in the AOPA magazine of April 1996. On page 3 it says:

. . . I especially thank our `Fax Brigade', the front‐line troops who have made our views known by fax, `phone and letter. I thank those members who have trudged the halls of Parliament House; the members who have attended all those parliamentary hearings; the people who donated money and time to the coalition's election campaign; those who attended all the political events, quietly saying, `we are AOPA.'
I salute our President, Dick Smith, whose personal part in the election campaign was enormous. A wonderful team effort has produced a superlative result, and now it is up to all of us to make the most of it.
He goes on later to say:
CASA is well‐known for retribution.
That's one of the things that has to be changed. We will never have a better opportunity to do it than now.
That sentence is in bold type.

Look at the political situation. A new Minister has just taken over. If he finds things are wrong now, he can correct them and it's a positive event because they are clearly the responsibility of the former Minister, Laurie Brereton. Six months from now—
and six months have not elapsed yet—
that won't be true. A year from now any problem in CASA will be the Minister's responsibility and his alone.
On page 18, in another article, which is like an editorial but is not by‐lined, he refers to the minister and says:
His Government have also said they will appoint members to the boards of both CASA and Airservices Australia who have real aviation experience.

I refer you back to his words `never have a better opportunity than to do it now'. But let me go on. At page 24 of this organisation's policy—which they are entitled to have, and it is good to see they have put their minds to it—they refer to industry partnership between the bureaucracy as one of their objectives. They say:
Industry Partnership between the bureaucracy and operators rather than mistrust and mis‐communication.

In a matter like this, it is not a question of partnership. A safety regulator is there to protect the travelling public, not to be in partnership with those who are to be checked or those who are to be regulated. That is not their role, but that is the policy of this organisation.

What worries me even more is the tone of this. We come to page 88. The article is headed `From the desk of the CEO Bart Beech', and I am just plucking out one small bit of it in the time that is available. `Today's aviation environment' is one of the subheadings. It goes on to say:
It won't happen overnight, but it will happen! Relations with CASA are at a low ebb, with Leroy Keith threatening Boyd Munro with action under the Crimes Act.

Those comments are very serious comments. I have made them in this place, they are in a public document, but from this moment on the minister is at risk. This organisation has compromised him. He, by his own comments on other occasions, has linked up with that, and I fear for the future of aviation safety in this country. You cannot conduct that responsibility with those kinds of relationships. All of those parties who are involved are accountable to this parliament and to the Australian public.

We go on then to Mr Smith. Firstly, you have to know where Mr Smith comes from. This is the Civil Aviation Authority annual report of 1990‐91 and the chairman's comment. In this chairman's comment he refers to restructuring. He says that it will be completed in 1991‐92 with progressively improved services and cost savings. In that document is a table for the reduction of staff from 727 in January 1991 down to 434 in January 1992, which is a month prior to the departure of chairman Dick Smith. But, if you look at the composition of the board
of which Mr Smith was the chairman and you read their background, it makes a farce of the comments of the minister and of Mr Smith and of everybody else who peddled this line about, `Put me on the board. Let me run the show because I fly an aeroplane or I used to fly an aeroplane. I know all.' I do not have time to pull that together; I will do it at a later stage.

The great mass of the people who use aeroplanes in this country are the people who use the major airlines, the regional airlines and the charter airlines, not the recreation fliers or the hobby fliers. We do not want the tail wagging the dog or the tip of the tail wagging the dog. The responsibility is to the people of this country, the major users of aviation services. If you go through and read who the members of that board were at that time when Mr Smith was chairman, as I said, it makes a farce of the comments that the minister is now making and that have been made by Mr Smith and other people.
But let me turn now to the coroner's report about Mr Smith. This is the coroner's report on the air crash of the Monarch Airlines aircraft at Young on 11 June 1993. It says on page 8:

A former Chairman of the CAA had advocated a policy of `affordable safety' which favoured a very lenient approach to policing the regulations. `Affordable safety' does not necessarily equate to `necessary safety'; in effect, it was up to each airline to decide if it was affordable to fly safely. If a plane crashes the airline is up for the cost of the plane; if the passengers and pilots are killed or injured and the airline has no assets or insurance to cover that contingency then the risk is `affordable' to the airline.
This is not a Morris document; this is the coroner's report and I have quoted faithfully from it.

Mr Smith responded to that on the
7.30 Report
on Monday, 10 June when asked a question about whether the skies over Australia were safer before or since his time as chairman. He said:

For example, the first full year I was there, there was only one commercial passenger fatality. The year that I left there was zero, and that was because of hard work. We grounded aeroplanes. I read that coroner's report and it gets me mad because it's full of lies.

Again, it is not a politician's statement; it is the coroner's report into a grave tragedy. The responses of the former chairman, and he who would be chairman, and of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, and any other organisation under the purview of this government, have been, `That report is full of lies.' The lawyers will sort that out. If the report is full of lies, that will be disclosed by the lawyers in the litigation that obviously will flow from it.

But I keep coming back to the point that I am greatly worried by what I see and what I hear. There are influences at work—some are seen and some are unseen—and there are obviously nods and winks involved in all of this. Then I turn to our report and Mr Smith's claim that safety was best in his year of office. That is a nonsense. We dealt with this in the report. The current minister was a party to this unanimous report and the working committee that prepared the report. He knows, as I know, what Mr Smith did, and the words that we wrote about that.

Mr Smith removed crew members who died in the crash and the reason given for this fatal accident was crew foolishness. A government decision was that regulations should protect third party and property, not people. In other words, if a crew member died, he did not count that because a crew member should not have conducted himself or herself in a way that led to his or her death.

Then he wanted to include balloon passengers. I do not know of any regular public transport service that transports people by balloon. You can have joy rides in them. But he included
balloons in one year and excluded crew deaths in another year. The committee's words which start in paragraph 3.30 were:

This is an arbitrary and absurd way of compiling and interpreting statistics. Similarly, it is very doubtful whether ballooning accidents qualify for inclusion in official statistics because ballooning is not a recognised mode of transport . . . There are very broad and general reasons for causal connections. If Smith had been able to show, for example, that outputs had increased (eg increased number of ramp checks)—
that is, that more work had been done
. . . this may have given some credibility to his claims.
It is a nonsense that is made by this man who would be chairman of any other organisation within the reach of this government.

Then I go on further to the matter, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I mentioned to you the other day in your capacity as chairman of the communications, transport and micro‐economic reform committee, and that is the advice to you by the minister in his letter of 20 June. It says:
As you are aware, I recently publicly foreshadowed a review of Australia's aviation safety regulations—
and so on. He continues:

I envisage that the issues identified in the Plane Safe Report of December 1995 . . . will be among the matters considered as part of this review. Accordingly, I consider that any further consideration of such aviation safety matters by the Committee should await completion of the foreshadowed regulatory review. I will ensure that the Committee is kept fully briefed on the work of the review.

That adds to my worry. In this letter the minister said: `Aviation safety inquiry examination is out of bounds for this committee. The unanimous report to the parliament adopted in full by the previous minister and in process of being implemented, we are looking at again. There are several revisions yet to come, but that committee is out of bounds for them.'

I do not know whether the minister, with the best will in the world, is fully aware of the implications of this, and I am putting my comments to him in this way: I do not know whether he really realises what he has created and the situation in which he has been placed. I suspect in a way that he is being manipulated. It is a bit like the artificially inseminated cow: she knows that something is happening, but she is not quite sure how it is happening.

If it were something of a trivial nature, I would not be so concerned; we could laugh about it. But, in this case, this is the most important safety matter in this nation, next to some medical matter or a plague, or something of that nature. The millions of Australians that travel by air are entitled to expect that aviation safety regulation matters will be administered properly. When they are on a plane up there, those safety regulations should be inviolate. They should not be influenced by personal grudges, financial interests, briefs, or anything else. What worries me greatly is that comment in AOPA's magazine about Leroy Keith.

I read through the minister's statement a few days ago on the review of regulations that is going to be announced tomorrow. Again, he has put himself in the position where, on the one hand, he is attacking staff members of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. I do not know who is writing this stuff for him. I do not know who is providing this advice. But whoever it is obviously does not understand the ramifications of what they have done to their minister. They have sat him up there nicely; he is sitting on the point of the spear. He is not going to be able to move one millimetre—forwards, backwards or sideways—because you cannot, as a minister, be accountable to the parliament, be responsible for aviation safety in this country and, at the same time, be hammering the people that are responsible for carrying out that policy.

break.para:
I am pleased that the minister has come into the committee room, because I want him to hear what I have to say. I hope he will look at
Hansard
and read what I have already said. I fear for you, Minister. I fear for the position in which you have been placed. But you cannot, as a minister, on the one hand, be hammering people in the organisation, unnamed, and, at the same time, be expressing confidence in that organisation's ability to carry out its task.

So in this legislation, simple as it is, the board membership does not matter. It does not matter whether it is three, whether it is nine, or whether it is 10. It is what is behind it, Minister. It is what advice you are being given, and I do not think you are being given the benefit of the best advice that is available or impartial advice. But the position has now changed. As Boyd Munro says, in six months—come 2 September—you will be responsible for everything. Today is 27 June. There is not long to go. That is why I would have been much happier if I had seen in what you were doing, what you were saying in respect of our report and what you were saying in respect of this matter, something that much more closely adhered to the views you had and the utterances you made as a member of the committee, in the valuable work that you carried out in the preparation of the
Plane safe
report. All of that unfinished business has gone on hold.
So I put those views. I am deeply concerned about them. I hope that the minister will listen. As I have said, if I can help him in any way in respect of those matters, I am only too happy to do that.

speech.speaker: Andren, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the purpose of the amendments that I have circulated is to give the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) the power to dismiss the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and to appoint a new board made up of members with aviation experience. As a member for an area with strong commercial and private aviation activity, I am most concerned for the safety of regional aviation in particular. When he was in opposition, the minister was recognised around Australia as one of CASA's outspoken critics. He has been an outspoken and authoritative spokesman for air safety and has done much to elevate this issue to national debate, particularly after the Seaview and Monarch crashes.

speech.para: So, I believe the minister has a mandate to honour his pre‐election commitment to appoint to the board people with appropriate aviation experience, not simply to dilute a board appointed by a former minister by adding two new members. It is completely at odds with the coalition's pre‐election promise to reduce the size of government. Only one member of the existing board has any previous aviation experience. Appointing two new members with experience will not ensure that the board that oversees aviation safety in this country will still have a majority of members with aviation experience. I accept that the government may be forced to pay out fees for those directors it would remove, but I believe that would be a small price to pay to reassure public confidence in our aviation industry.

Mr Deputy Speaker, Australians once took pride in having the world's safest aviation industry. The Seaview and Monarch crashes have critically undermined that confidence. We are talking about a board specifically charged with aviation safety—not the ABC or a public service board—and that places special onus on the government and the minister. The recent findings of the Monarch inquest display the serious shortcomings in overseeing the safety standards in our industry. While the current board certainly cannot be blamed for the Monarch disaster, the fact remains that the people who let those operators continue to fly are still doing
the same job for CASA as they did for the Civil Aviation Authority—a slur over those with impeccable records.

However, these people, who are now giving advice to the new board, were in place when a plane carrying two young men crashed in the Blue Mountains en route to Forbes on 3 October 1993. But for a mobile ELT—emergency locator transmitter—Scott Grezl and Hamish Wallace could well be alive today. They died slow and lingering deaths, over many hours in one case, and perhaps 15 days in another; their plane, and its fixed ELT, burnt beyond any use. The ELT was in fact inoperative, out of sight, out of mind and not hand‐held. As a news editor covering this protracted case, I spoke with relatives and investigators and was horrified at the waste of these lives and in fact the entire search process.

The current board of CASA still refuses, as I understand it, to approve portable ELTs, although they are in use in jumbos. I do not believe the current board has the expertise to make a sound judgment on this or on any other air safety issue nor will it have majority expertise under the government's proposals. It is essential that public confidence in our aviation industry is restored. It is essential that the federal parliament shows leadership on this issue and does not just take the easy way out. The Civil Aviation Amendment Bill, as it stands, is a Clayton's bill: the one you have when you don't have a bill. My amendments give this bill the clout it needs, and it effectively precludes any spill over of the legislation into other areas so it will not impact on other statutory bodies.

I have reason to believe many aircraft operators, including major operators, are strongly opposed to what they see as a weak response by the minister to a serious problem. Max Hazelton, the founder of Hazelton Airlines, a regional operator in my electorate with an enviable safety record, also sees an urgent need for real change and that can only come from an experienced board. These amendments are designed to allow the minister to address what the industry and the flying public require—that is, the need for the government to control the efficiency and, most importantly, the safety of the airline industry.

In his own words to parliament this week, the transport minister expressed concern that the old CAA culture still existed despite a change of name. He also said that he is not satisfied that CASA has responded fully to a report into the DC3 crash into Botany Bay in 1994. He said:
It will be a major tragedy if the only thing that has happened is that the shingle on the front door is changed.
That `major tragedy' metaphor may come back to haunt the minister, and us all, if decisive action is not taken now.

I have no problems with the board. I do not know the members of the board. Gabi Hollows is a wonderful person. Justice Fisher an honourable man with a proud record, but not in this critical area. Those comments from the minister this week constitute a vote of no confidence, an argument for a new board with the confidence of the government, the minister and therefore the public.

Press reports today talk of a showdown looming between the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the minister. CASA's chairman has described the minister's comments as defamatory, saying that the current board was set up with the capacity to resist pressure groups, including those supported by the minister. The member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) speaks of nods and winks. I have seen enough of that in politics over the years from the outside and I guess, in many ways, that is why I am here. Nodding and winking is a past habit of governments
of all persuasions but I do not believe this is about nodding and winking at all. It is about that essential safety in an essential industry. The constitution of that board must reign far and above any other board and the statutory constitutions of it.

I have heard the name Dick Smith mentioned in this debate. I do not know who the minister might want on his board. I certainly do not have any suggestions. I leave that to people with more expertise. But I do know the gulf between the current board and its minister is now so wide that the public should be appalled at the prospect of a continuing relationship between this board, this minister and air safety.

The member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) spoke of the fact that we may never get another airport in Sydney. That, I believe, could be a factor in the next ten years at least, and it will only exacerbate the safety concerns that we have in the airline industry. I also noticed that the minister has referred to the transport and infrastructure committee, I think it is, a reference on air freight. I suggest that that committee look seriously, and I mean seriously, at the Parkes airport proposal as not only a freight option but perhaps a hub and spoke passenger option as well.

I have had indications that the government will not support my amendments even though it favours them. It has been suggested to me that my delaying the bill's passage is cementing in place the board that does not have the minister's additions to it. The minister's amendment on the structure of the board is a Clayton's amendment. Any delay is not my problem. My problem is the safety of the air travelling public and the need for a minister to have full confidence in the board, and through them, the organisation charged with air safety. The minister's problem can be easily solved. Support my amendments. I will be seeking a detailed discussion and that this bill go back to the House with an unresolved question.

speech.speaker: Sharp, John, MP

talker.name: Mr SHARP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

talk.start.para: —I commence by thanking all those members who have contributed to this debate. It is always worthwhile having a debate on subjects like this and the second chamber does provide us with the opportunity to do that. You can virtually guarantee the sorts of people who will get up and speak and, in some cases, you can guarantee what they will say before they have said it. Needless to say, it is always an interesting debate when you talk about aviation matters.

speech.para: Keeping an eye on what has been said earlier today, I would like to pass a few comments in relation to previous speakers. Firstly, I refer to some comments made by the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) and thank him for his contribution. I note his comments in regard to the EIS guidelines. They are the responsibility of the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), who will be drawing those up. It is my hope that that will be done as quickly as possible because this process needs to be set in place as quickly as we can to alleviate concerns in Sydney about the site for a second airport.

The honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) was up to his usual game of politics, as ever, and made a number of comments, one of which related to the campaign of the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) in the recent election. The honourable member for Watson somewhat changed some of the promises made by the now member for Lowe by claiming that Mr Zammit had promised there would be no aeroplanes over the seat of Lowe if you voted for him but that there would be aeroplanes over the seat of Lowe if you voted for Mary Easson, the then sitting member for the Labor Party.

That is not a true and accurate account of the promises made by the now member for Lowe in his election campaign. The commitments at that time were that there would be no new flight
paths. The reference there to `new' was in relation to flight paths that existed prior to November 1994. Prior to the opening of the third runway there were a number of well-established flight paths that existed in the electorate of Lowe and the commitment was that there would be no new flight paths. Certainly, to our knowledge to date, that commitment has not been broken. So it is inaccurate and unfair of the member for Watson to try to interpret the words of the member for Lowe during the election campaign and try, therefore, to paint him as not having lived up to the promises he made in that campaign.

He also said that our decision to introduce slots for Sydney airport was a ruse to raise revenue, as I think he put it, and that we would sell these slots off to the highest bidder. That is not our intention. We are negotiating with industry at the present time as to the best mechanism we can use. We are setting up two committees in industry to assist us in coming to a proper and fair mechanism for the allocation of slots.

One of the things I want to assure the House about, and this would be of particular interest to the member for Calare (Mr Andren), being a representative of a regional area, particularly one that is so noted for its aviation services, is that there will be dedicated slots for Sydney airport for regional airline operations. We can guarantee through this process that regional airline operations will still have access to Mascot airport.

That is something that I know regional representatives from the New South Wales area would be particularly interested in. And I, of course, representing a regional part of New South Wales with a number of aviation services currently flying into Mascot Airport, would also view it as important that, in establishing a slot process for Sydney's airport operations, regional airlines are given their fair share of those slots. That is part of the process. We are going to guarantee that. Indeed, if we did not do it this way, the possibilities of regional airline operations being squeezed out of Mascot would be much greater if we did not have a proper slot management process. That is what the slot allocation process is all about.

I will also talk about the comments made by the honourable member for Watson in regard to affordable safety. He belittled the terminology and the philosophy behind it. Whilst affordable safety is not a term I would necessarily use myself, I think you cannot argue the logic of affordable safety. Everything that we do in life in relation to safety is measured by our ability to afford it. We only have limited resources to allocate to safety and we have to allocate them to the best of our ability.

If we did not do that, everybody would own a Mercedes motorcar, because we know Mercedes motorcars are safer in car crashes than driving around in a Volkswagen. Yet Mercedes motorcars are more expensive than Volkswagens, therefore people in their normal daily lives have to make a judgment about safety based upon their ability to afford it. So the logic of affordable safety is just a fact of life; it is something we cannot deny. I do not know whether I would have necessarily used the terminology. At any rate, it has been used. But the honourable member for Watson should not be mischievous in trying to denigrate the philosophy behind that.

Can I now go to the comments by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). As always in these debates he is a contributor, and a well‐considered contributor, being someone with considerable knowledge and interest in this area over a lengthy period of time, and also as a pilot who learnt many years ago and as an active person in the aviation community. Can I say to the honourable member, because he would be very interested in and committed to the recommendations of the
Plane safe
report, which is the result of the
committee he chaired, that we are undertaking work now to ensure that we can pick up those recommendations. It would be my view, having been a member of that committee, that there is a great deal of sense, logic and gain to be had by implementing recommendations in the
Plane safe
report.

talk.start.para: —You wrote a lot of it, didn't you?

—I wrote a lot of it myself, as the honourable member for Shortland points out. So it is obviously a very clever document! There is a lot of logic in it and we would be interested in doing that. In particular, the manner of reporting deficiencies for airline operators is an initiative that should be implemented as quickly as we can. Indeed, it frustrates me at times that we are not doing it faster, but we will do it.

speech.para: I also thank the honourable member for Calare for his contribution. I appreciate the sentiment of his amendments and I appreciate the words that he has expressed here today. I particularly take note of his comments in regard to ELTs and the example he used of those two young gentlemen who were killed as a consequence of their aeroplane crashing in the Blue Mountains. They survived the crash—indeed, were not all that injured in the crash—but their ELT, which was fixed to the aircraft, did not go off and they perished several days later.

That is a very good example as to why we need to look more carefully at the ELT issue. We have done that and we have made a judgment, with the support of the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, which we believe is a sensible one. That is now to be implemented very shortly. I thank the honourable member for Calare for making those comments.

Can I just remind members of the House that the purpose behind this bill is to ensure that we can deliver on our election commitments. I see the honourable member for Shortland questioning whether we have the support of the board in regard to ELTs. I am pretty sure I can even provide you with the correspondence, and I shall shortly.

talk.start.para: —I thought you said—
—Order!

—I think you will find that the advice from the Civil Aviation Safety Authority was that they recognised that there was merit and enhanced safety in the decision that we made. So I will provide you with a copy of that.
—I thought it was a direction.
—No, it was not a direction.
—Order! The minister should not respond to interjections.
—I am just making sure that members on the other side understand what I say.
—There is no prohibition on having both.

—No. We will not have a discussion across the table, otherwise we will run out of time and the Deputy Speaker will pull me up. Can I just say that the purpose of expanding the size of the board was to deliver on our commitment made during the election campaign, which was to ensure that we had people on the board of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority who had aviation expertise. That was a genuine commitment we made. When we came into government we endeavoured to see that fulfilled. Of course, under the legislation, we were unable to dismiss the board and to appoint new people. The honourable member for
Calare made that point in his speech. We take the view that it is important that the board members have a relationship with the industry that is cohesive and cooperative.

speech.para: I think it is a terribly important issue that we do have people running our safety regulator who have appropriate qualifications and experience in aviation. For those of you who disagree with that, my reference to you would be the Monarch coroner's report that was released only a couple of weeks ago, in which he outlined some of the very serious deficiencies in the old CAA that existed at the time of the Monarch crash. It is a damning indictment of the old CAA.

Whilst the structure of the old CAA has changed and we now have two organisations, the simple fact of the matter is that those organisations are still staffed nearly completely by the same people who were there before. There have been structural changes, but they have not necessarily led to a cultural change. In order to ensure that the culture of the CASA, the regulator, and the performance of that body are at their maximum and delivering the best safety system for Australian air travellers, we must have people who know what they are talking about—people who do have appropriate experience and qualifications.

I note—the honourable member for Calare referred to it in his address today—the comments of the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, criticising me for attacking the Civil Aviation Safety Authority in my speech in the House on Tuesday of this week. I make the point that—

talk.start.para: —And attacking the board.

—I make the point, though, that, as the person ultimately responsible to the parliament and to the people of Australia for aviation safety in this country, I take it as an important right of mine to make criticism where it is appropriate and to give praise where it is due. If I am not allowed to make those sorts of criticisms or give that sort of praise, then I find that extraordinary. Justice Fisher's criticisms of me were partly based on the fact that I dared to criticise the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, its staff and its board members. That is, indeed, my duty, as I understand it, and I will not shirk that responsibility.

speech.para: Can I also make the point that Justice Fisher's criticisms of me in his press release of yesterday run completely contrary to the letter that he sent me in April of this year. He says in his letter why he believes he should continue to stay on and how he can justify his decision to stay on as the chairman of the board. He says:
You may rely on my own and the Board's loyal support for your administration as Minister limited only by our statutory duty to determine matters independently.

Justice Fisher in his comments yesterday, and in comments that he has made in press releases since he wrote that letter, contradicts himself and draws into question whether the intent of his statement in the letter I have just quoted from is actually being delivered upon. I know some people say—indeed, Justice Fisher would say—that he is appropriately qualified for the task. Justice Fisher is a lawyer. He is a judge. He is somebody who has some occupational safety expertise. But, again, none of that expertise that he has—no matter how well qualified he may be in those areas—is relevant to aviation.

Looking at other members of the board, there are only four members, only one of whom has aviation experience: Geoff Molloy. Of the other two members, Dr Claire Pollock is a systems analyst from Western Australia and is no doubt highly qualified in her area and a very responsible person, but I make the point in this speech that she has no experience relevant to aviation. It is the same with Gabi Hollows, who is—as members have pointed out—a wonderful person, a person whom Australians can look up to. Again, her qualifications, as
described by Justice Fisher, are as a consumer advocate. She is not a member of any consumer organisations that I am aware of. She, like many hundreds of thousands of Australians who use commercial aviation, could be judged as a consumer advocate. Therefore, again, she has no experience relevant to aviation.

That is why this legislation is before the House today. It is important for us to have people who have relevant expertise and experience in aviation administering aviation safety regulation on a day‐to‐day basis for us. Unfortunately, of the four non‐executive directors of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority board, only one has any relevant experience; the others do not—hence the principle behind the Civil Aviation Safety Act amendment that we have put before the parliament at this time.

I go to the particular amendments to the bill. I thank the member for Calare for his proposed amendments and for the sentiments behind them. However, the intent of the amendments go well beyond what the government would propose, which is simply to ensure that the board has members with appropriate aviation experience. They touch on broader policy issues which relate to statutory authorities generally, and the coalition government will address those issues separately.

I thank the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner), for his amendment to the motion for the second reading. I consider his first point inappropriate, as the bill before the House does not preclude appointment of people with the types of experience suggested. On his second point, I would have to question the intent of the provision, and I do not consider that the House can provide such a broad test to this, or any other, board. It seems, therefore, that the opposition may have a vendetta against an individual or individuals.

It is extraordinarily hypocritical on the part of the opposition that, when in government, it made appointments such as that of Bill Kelty to the Board of the Reserve Bank, yet would now require the House to limit this government with regard to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The government does not therefore support the amendment to the motion for the second reading.

I conclude by saying that this is a very important issue. I know everybody has their personal views about particular people and particular processes, and that they have some loyalties to those people and processes. But I say to the House that this is a very important issue. I know the people who have spoken on this bill treat it as such. We have seen a number of accidents in recent years which can be attributed in part to the failure of the Civil Aviation Authority of old. Indeed, it could well be that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority at this time is still not sufficiently reformed to ensure that we have an authority that is going to deliver the safest aviation regime for Australia. It is a very serious matter. We should not treat it lightly.

I thank members who have contributed to this debate. The thing that we take as an overriding principle in all of this is that, in an area that is so important to the safety of millions of Australians every year, we have people on the board governing the safety regulator who have appropriate experience and qualifications and understand the technical aspects of aviation and its language, history and culture, and who therefore are in a position to make sensible, proper and appropriate judgments without delay, thus ensuring that people who use our air services around Australia have an organisation regulating aviation safety that is driven by the best possible available expertise.

interject.speaker: DEPUTY SPEAKER

talk.start.para:
—The original question was that this bill be now read a second time. To this, the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) has moved an amendment
that all words after `that' be omitted, with a view to substituting other words. The immediate question is that the words proposed to be omitted stand as part of the question.

interject.para: Question unresolved.

interject.speaker: DEPUTY SPEAKER

talk.start.para: —As honourable members would be aware, the standing orders do not provide for divisions in this chamber. So, as it is necessary to resolve this question to enable further questions to be considered in relation to this bill, in accordance with standing order 277, the bill will be returned to the House for further consideration.
