debate.sub1.title: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee

proctext.para:
Debate resumed from 30 May, on motion by
Mr Reith
:
That the House take note of the paper.

speech.speaker: Price, Roger, MP

talk.start.para: —In my haste to get up here, I actually left some notes of mine behind. But I have had time to carefully go through the government response, and I would like to say a few things, including some that I said when the report was tabled.

speech.para: This was a bipartisan committee. The report reflected the good work of all committee members. I am a little disappointed that some of those members, for one reason or another, were not returned to the parliament.

I guess that when you table reports you do not expect that all of the recommendations will be embraced. I think that is true of this report. As I said when I tabled this report, I felt that it was not so much that the recommendations would be tested as that, rather, the government's response would be tested against how many of the recommendations were adopted. Whilst I understood that some might provide difficulty, I was really surprised at how many were rejected.

Perhaps the most controversial proposal was the abolition of the undergraduate program at ADFA, and its replacement with a scholarship scheme. I think it is fair to say that committee opinion varied; there were a range of views, from strongly endorsing it to thinking it should at least be considered. Therefore, I find the minister's response—and the government's response—to the recommendation particularly poor. I think it is a little mendacious and somewhat cavalier, if not irresponsible.

I will just go through the arguments again, because I have been attacked in the paper over this. We spend $200 million on the professional development of some 11,000 officers. There are about 1,000 officer cadets at ADFA. They consume $100 million. The scholarship scheme would save $60 million. If you paid for the 1,000 university places from the defence budget and put in additional places in the 37 other universities, the saving would be $50 million. That is not an inconsiderable saving. Defence applies a number of methodologies to its approach to all aspects of its work. One is `value for money'—those are not my words. ADFA does not, I believe, survive that first and most basic test: providing value for money.

Secondly, the previous government introduced a commercial support program which really suggested that defence needed to stick to its defence kitty for core activities, and that individuals or private enterprises could provide services: that there ought to be a competitive
regime, and the most successful tenderer should win. They have been doing this for some years.

Is it argued that the training of undergraduates is a core activity of the Defence Department? I do not believe it. Indeed, there are 37 other universities who graduate 132,000 students. ADFA graduates 300 a year. I think it is absolutely preposterous to suggest that developing undergraduates is a core activity of the Defence Department.

There has been some light‐hearted reference, if you like, to this idea that there is value in the future officer corps of Australia understanding their cohorts' values and beliefs, as they would if they were going to other universities. That is, given that the ADF seeks to serve the community, the community is important to the ADF and you cannot start this too early. I passionately believe that. But it is suggested that, if some of the female cadets play netball and the men put their bums in a scrum, somehow they have these wonderful discussions about belief systems, values and attitudes where this is all picked up on their sporting activities. This is just absolute nonsense.

But, most importantly of all the arguments, the particular one I wish to advance has received too little attention. That is that when young people have determined upon a career, have narrowed it down and have signed up for that career, they want to get into the action as quickly as possible. What ADFA does is incarcerate them straight out of high school, and it can be up to six years after signing on to be an infantryman, or to drive a ship or to pilot a plane, before they actually do it. I suspect this large gap has an impact on separation rates and I challenge the minister, in his cavalier rejection of the recommendation, to look at the separation rates. Just start watching those separation rates, because I suspect there is every chance that ADFA graduates may have higher separation rates than the rest.

There are some other arguments I want to advance as well. It is said that this provides a unique environment to inculcate the military ethos and the profession of arms. If it is so unique, if it is so beneficial, why don't all officers go through it? Why don't we scrap direct entry and why don't we put all other rank officer candidates through ADFA? Of course, there is a simple reason: we cannot afford it. That is the first thing. Let me propose something you may find faintly ridiculous. If this is so important, if this is so essential and everything that follows after ADFA has so little impact on military ethos and the profession of arms, why don't we start incarceration at age 13? Why don't we have a sister high school, or several high schools, located in and around ADFA and we will start this incarceration process at that age? It is a ridiculous argument. But then I think the opposition has been ridiculous as well.

I also want to completely reject the argument that it is too early to judge. I do not care what the institution is that we establish, it is always appropriate that there be reviews and finetuning and that people have an opportunity to revisit the issue. There is the suggestion that it is only when we get a CDF who has graduated from ADFA that we will know for certain whether the institution has served us well or not served us well. Certainly, in relation to ADFA, within the committee the range of opinions was from `strongly for' to `at least ought to be considered'. I am the first one to acknowledge it. But I must say I am particularly disappointed in the response.

I want to cover a few other issues and one of them is jointery. I believe jointery was pioneered in a very good way at ADFA. But I do not believe that the ADF can continue with the farce of saying that one of the best features of ADFA is jointery—and I accept that—but we are going to preclude people from jointery until they get up to the Command and Staff
College. You cannot be half in and half out. If jointery is worthwhile, we need to maintain it. That is why I still stand by the committee's recommendation about looking at the feasibility of a tri‐service pre‐commissioning college.

The government's rejection of co‐locating the separate colleges—that is, the WRAN Staff College, the Army Command and Staff College and the RAAF Command and Staff College, all integrated into a tri‐service ADF Command and Staff College located in Canberra, with the common military curriculum and tri‐service elements in it—I find appalling. It was one of the things that really surprised me. I note in the government response that they are going to do a further review.

They propose, at best, the co‐locating of the three colleges; all in one location but with no common military core training and no integration of the colleges. We will have three colleges smack‐bang in the one location. What an absolute farce. There may be some savings in that, but they would be minuscule. It will not be jointery. It goes completely against the thrust of that. I would be surprised if this approach attracted the support of the Public Works Committee, whom they will inevitably have to consult. I am absolutely convinced that one day we will see tri‐service pre‐commissioning and we will see a single command and staff college with common subjects and single‐service elements in it as well.

One issue in the committee's report which I had thought was understood—in fact, I thought it was quite reasonable—was, again, rejected. It was that there are two elements to officer training. The first is the officers' professional development and education, which we were privileged to review and which the nine separate colleges all administer, at a cost of $200 million. The second element is the war fighting skills that are inevitably associated with the profession of arms. This was outside the terms of reference of the committee—and, in fact, having reviewed it, I do not know that any committee of the parliament would feel too comfortable about it—but, having made what I think were fairly fundamental and significant recommendations for change on the one side, if you were going to change any of that, you really needed to have looked at the other side and made sure that it all fitted into a continuum. That particular recommendation has been really misunderstood, as far as I can tell, in the government's response.

I would like to return to a couple of things about the scholarship scheme. What incredibly bad timing it was to table this report on the day of national protest, when every university campus was up in arms about possible loss of staff, loss of funding or increases in HECS! The most pampered, gold plated institution in Australia will not lose one staff member, and we will not be saving one dollar of expenditure. Under the scholarship proposal recommended in the committee's report, it is nonsense to say that the ADF cannot be guaranteed a supply of university graduates. This is the only way, as the government's response tries to argue.

Let me refer to the number of students previously. In 1993, in science, engineering, humanities and arts, which are the faculties that ADFA draws from, a total of 132,860 students graduated. To say that offering a scholarship for these people would not guarantee a supply is rubbish. The ready reserve scheme puts people with a university degree into the officer corp, it puts people into the reserve and also into the other ranks. I happen to think that is a good thing.

In conclusion, I think there are a couple of things that will be of absolute and fundamental significance to Defence. The first is the Glenn review, which has been published, and the second is Army 21. I also want to acknowledge, as I did previously, the contributions of the
right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) to the committee's report. The work of this committee is not inconsistent with the direction of those other two works and I think as time goes by we will see them implemented.
(Time expired)

speech.speaker: Sinclair, Ian, MP

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to speak on this. In saying that to you, I also extend to the government the fact that I think it is important, when there is a response from the government on a committee's recommendations, that there is an opportunity to debate them either here or, preferably, in the other place. By `the other place', I mean the main chamber.

speech.para: I am always conscious that time is of the essence but I guess I am one of the few people around this place who thinks we are mad having two weeks on and two weeks off. I am one of those who thinks we were far better when we sat for three weeks and had one week off. It gave continuity to debate, allowed for reasonable consideration of issues and we got far more out of parliament. I know this Main Committee is an adjunct, and that we are all given a chance to say our tuppence worth, but I still feel that it does not equate with the capacity to debate issues in parliament. I see it as an excuse rather than anything else. I think it is very important that we do not just set aside forever the nature and character of discussions regarding the function of this Main Committee and the House. I hope that, at some stage, we can revert back to having more debate within the parliament itself, particularly on issues such as this.

I am delighted to see that some cadets have come in to listen to us. I welcome them to this place because they have come at a time when we are debating an issue that relates, in one sense, to their futures. The former chair of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and, prior to that, the chair of the subcommittee on Defence, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) is also here, as is the former secretary, Ms Gillian Gould. I am delighted to see Gillian here. Gillian put a lot of effort into her Defence commitment and indeed is one of the few who went to the Joint Services Staff College. For those of you who are cadets, it is down near the sewerage farm, down that end of town! I can assure you that those who come out of the college are far different from that that goes into the adjacent works. It is a very worthwhile facility and one which is part of the area that we examine in this report.

I now turn to a few issues in the report itself. If governments are going to respond to a committee's report, I do not think that they should present a response which is as inadequate as this. There is nothing more profound than trying to determine the direction and role of those of you who are trying to make a career in the forces. Because we have cadets here, let me say to them that they have all sorts of alternatives.

We all hope and pray that peace is maintained. And, as parliamentarians, we will do our utmost, in our respective ways, in whatever the party, to achieve and maintain peace. But we do not look at the future by saying that what we have will always be. There is nothing more fundamental than this particular issue which we are talking about in this chamber. We are talking here about the government's response to the report.

I had forgotten we had the bosses behind us; I should have stood and saluted them. I did not know we had all the high brass. Perhaps they would like to take part, as part of the officer education team.

We are talking about a report that was prepared by a committee of the parliament, called
Officer education: the military after next
. At the moment, we are dealing with the government's response. It is a very thin document. The report is quite a worthwhile tome, and
those of you interested in joining the services might find it worthwhile to read it. It has about 250 pages, and covers a large range of subjects pertaining to officer education.

Because I have only a few minutes, I want to talk about some of the detail. There are three areas, in particular, which I want to address. The first is staff colleges. The response by the government on staff colleges was, to say the least, totally inadequate. We all recognise that it is very hard for members of parliament to actually produce a report with sufficient analysis, detail and background for all of its recommendations to be implemented. But one area of officer education which stands out as needing reform is that of staff colleges.

For the audience, I will say that there are different levels of officer education, and staff colleges are the colleges to which officers go when they are at the captain or major level. They have been platoon commanders; in other words, they have had junior responsibilities and have looked after platoons. At the stage at which they move to becoming more administrative and embracing wider responsibilities, they go to staff colleges.

Demonstrably, the navy, the army and the air force each have different requirements. We may not have adequately addressed those in the report, but we certainly attempted to ensure that we looked at the requirements for each service and then looked at the combined requirements for tri‐service education. We felt that it was obvious that there needed to be some rebuilding of the facilities. The government has acknowledged that.

The government has also said it might look at collocating staff college facilities. But we went beyond that; we said that it would be a very good idea if the three staff colleges were collocated in Canberra and, within that combined staff college, you provided a combination that provided, in some part, for common education across the three services. Although you may be wearing an army uniform, there will quite often be a requirement for you to work with members of the other two armed forces. I think it is particularly important that that tri‐service education at the staff colleges be promoted.
Frankly, I do not accept the government's response to this. I feel that the integration of the three staff colleges is not only desirable but essential. I believe that, in addition to tri‐service training, you can provide supplementary individual training to meet the differing requirements of the three services. For example, the naval course is much shorter than the army course, but I do not accept that you cannot overcome that by giving each service whatever that service wants, in its particular form, after meeting what I see as an essential tri‐service obligation. So I certainly reject that part of this report.

The next part of the report that concerns me is the half‐baked response to our suggestion that distance education is a way by which you can supplement military education. One of the real problems is that many senior appointments in the services are made from among people who have had no opportunity to go to staff college. It is true that many of you may well go on to some form of tertiary education. Some of you might go to the services, some of you might go to university and some of you might go to TAFE. It does not matter where you go; in whatever career you follow, you will ultimately come to the position where that career is helped by the education you had before you got there. Where you have not had the opportunity to go to university or to do a particular course at a TAFE college, there are other opportunities, if you are in the civilian stream. Many of them are achieved through distance education.

I am a great advocate of distance education. While the government said that it supported the idea of distance education in principle, the response seemed to me to be very shallow. I do not accept the point that it makes that, to quote the response:

break.para: . . . staff college course content is such that distance learning cannot completely replace all the learning outcomes.

It cannot replace all of them, but you can provide some opportunity to have people in a staff college for a relatively short period of time, if you cannot send them there for 12 months. One of my worries with the staff college course is that 12 months is a long period to take out of a middle level officer's life, but there is no reason that you cannot take him in for occasional two‐week intensive periods and let him do some of the academic work by distance education. I thought that response was inadequate.

It is necessary that the services have more flexibility in the way in which they provide advanced training for their officers, and distance education is a very good way by which it can be achieved. Indeed, I have been interested to see, as I have moved around service facilities around Australia—and I commend them for it—how many senior officers have taken university degrees. A former senior officer is sitting alongside me at the moment: the member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who is a former Commodore in the Royal Australian Navy. He took several university degrees while he was a serving officer in the services.

The point is that there are ways by which you can combine intensive in‐service training by going to particular facilities. I see no reason why you cannot go to the tri‐service staff college, as we envisage, for whatever the period might be. It might be a fortnight or it might be a few weeks; but you could do it in such a way as to supplement that distance learning. I certainly think the services need to pursue that concept further.

Because the most fundamental of the recommendations related to ADFA, the Australian Defence Force Academy, and it was one of the prime recommendations of the committee—although not one that was universally endorsed—I wanted to say a few things before I close on that subject. There are three aspects to officer training that we need to consider. The first is the state of our economy. At the moment, because there is high unemployment, the nature of people entering at different levels of the Defence Force is different from that at a time of full employment.

Indeed, in the recruiting to the ready reserves, the number of young men and women who have joined the ready reserves, not just because they would like the opportunity, the discipline and the training but also because it is a vehicle by which they can get a tertiary education, has been remarkable. My worry about the employment market is that, as we move into full employment—and they are already having difficulties in recruiting sufficiently in each of the three services at ADFA—that position could get worse.

The second aspect, of course, is the security situation. As I began by saying, everyone hopes that peace will continue and, therefore, there is not a suggestion of having to recruit people for some urgent military confrontation. The third aspect is just as important, and that is to try to look at a phrase which I notice several people have criticised because they did not like it and which came from an academic from New Zealand. It has always appealed to me, and it is the term `the military after next'. Sure, it is a jargon phrase. It is like `multiculturalism'—a word which I do not particularly like but which covers something that we all understand.

When we talk about `the military after next', we are talking about the officers who are going to command the Australian Defence Force in the 21st century, and we try to look beyond those who are now serving to the character and nature of the force after the present one. We were trying to see whether we could augment present training opportunities. Again, we did not come down with a final, definitive recommendation; we looked at a number of flexible options.

My worry with the rejection of the committee's report is not that perhaps, after consideration, it may be too early for the change, but that to say that the report lacks substantive and sufficiently detailed reasoning to justify such a proposal—when the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) is now, properly, looking at university education right across Australia—seems to me to be saying, `It does not matter what is happening in every other tertiary institution in Australia, we are not going to look at what is happening at ADFA.'

That might be going too far but, frankly, there is justifiable reason for us to make sure that taxpayers get value for their dollar and that those who are students get the best possible education, and not just an education for education's sake. Really, education is what you remember when you have forgotten what you have learnt. When you leave school, those things which you remember are going to be the reason that you went to school. The learning that you do in order to pass exams or to become non‐commissioned or commissioned officers in the cadet corps or wherever is all the product of particular subjects. But education is something that lasts well beyond what you may forget in the day‐to‐day rigours of the subjects you take, either in the Defence Force or at school.

As far as ADFA is concerned, I think it is an excellent training opportunity, but I think it is too restricted. I do not believe that it necessarily provides the only way by which you can train future officers. I grant you that there are other ways of admission. Of all the evidence given to us, what struck me was the advice from the then commander of Duntroon, who told us that, six months after he had had ADFA cadets in Duntroon, he could not tell the difference between ADFA cadets and those who had come in as direct entry. I know that, certainly in the air force, where I have had some experience, often those who are very good officer material are not necessarily good pilots.

So, I am concerned at the response on ADFA. I think that it is too narrowly based. I think there is reason in looking at ways by which the initial entry of officer cadets can be modified and changed. I am disappointed that the government perhaps has not given more time and attention to what I see as fundamental in shaping the nature and character of the `military after next'.

speech.speaker: Taylor, Bill, MP

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I welcome the attendance in the gallery today of a number of my young constituents, who come from 13 Regional Cadet Unit, which is headquartered in Toowoomba.
—Hear, hear!

—In particular, I know that about 70 per cent of the group are prospective entrants into the Australian Defence Force. It was not tailored the way it happened this morning; it just happened that they were coming, and we thought that, rather than do the program that they were going to do, they should come and listen to something which was relevant to the future careers of a lot of them. So, I welcome them here this morning. I hope that what we have to say is of value to them.

speech.para:
In particular, I would like to pay tribute to one of their number, who is sitting right behind me over here—Major Bryce Rogers, who has just retired. Earlier in the week I did acknowledge in writing to Bryce the very substantial contribution that he has made to the cadet movement in southern Queensland, in the Toowoomba area, over many years—far more than perhaps he wants to remember. Nevertheless, he has made a very large contribution. These students here this morning, members of 13 RCU, are drawn from both public and private
schools in the Toowoomba area. I welcome them once again to listen to this debate—albeit a very abbreviated debate—on what is a very major subject.

Can I say first of all, Mr Deputy Speaker, that of course the cadet movement is important to the future of our nation and to the Australian Defence Force. I hope that, in the context of the 20 August budget, we will see some of the rhetoric of the coalition in opposition converted into substance. We did give an undertaking in the policy document, in the lead‐up to the election, that we would do something substantive in the area of cadets. I hope that that will, in fact, be carried through in the context of that budgetary setting.

So, with that said, it is a pleasure for me once again to stand in this Main Committee room and to talk briefly about this very important report and, in so doing, to follow two very eminent people—on the other side, and now in opposition, the former Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price); and, alongside me, a longstanding member, in fact the father of the House, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who is also, as I have said to the young people who are here today, a former and very eminent Minister for Defence.

I am sure that, if they take on board what Mr Sinclair has had to say briefly here today, it will stand them in good stead this afternoon when they go to the Australian Defence Force Academy. I thought it appropriate that they should come in and listen to some comments about a report which is very important to where a lot of them are heading.

I just want to mention three recommendations in this report. There are 23 recommendations in the report, and I agree with the right honourable member for New England in his criticism of the brevity of the government's response. I think it is perhaps a little too brief. But I have to say that I agree in general terms with what it has said. It goes back to the substance of what was in this very substantial document. As the right honourable member will recall, I did have some reservations, within the privacy of the joint standing committee. When the report was actually tabled, the wording was used so that people like me could stand up and, while not wanting to oppose what was being recommended, at least indicate that I had some strong reservations about some aspects of what it was recommending.

That is not to say that, as a former long‐serving naval officer, I was predisposed to a certain position in relation to the development of the officer corps, but that I thought that what was being proposed, particularly in relation to the Defence Force Academy, was premature, bearing in mind one or two points that I will come to in a moment. What I would like to do briefly is go through three particular recommendations—bearing in mind that, of the 23 recommendations, 13 have been accepted by the government either in principle or in part, or are under review. So it has been substantially agreed to by the government in a lot of areas. But, as in some of the points made by the right honourable member for New England, some of the areas where the committee recommended a major change have not been followed through.

The three areas that I would like to briefly address are, first, pre‐commissioning colleges; secondly, staff colleges; and, thirdly, the Defence Force Academy. In relation to the pre‐commissioning colleges, which are in recommendation 11 of the report, I think in hindsight—although I did make this point in the context of the committee hearings and in the development of the report—that too much emphasis was put on the need for jointery. For the benefit of 13 RCU, what we mean by that is the degree to which the army, navy and air force are working together in a very disciplined and formalised sense. I felt—and it has been the feeling of the
government response—that perhaps it is too early to do that, although I have to say that the response also indicates that it is an open door and they will continue to review that.

The existing single service colleges—whether they be at Point Cook, Duntroon or Jervis Bay—are making a major contribution in terms of the non‐degree stream. Perhaps we should not move as quickly as the report was indicating should be done in the very short term. So I tend to agree with the government response on recommendation 11. But, at the same time, I also agree with the right honourable gentleman that the response is somewhat brief—some would say too brief. But the door is open and it will continue to be reviewed within the Department of Defence and within the three services. That is the first point on recommendation 11 on pre‐commissioning colleges and the need to perhaps continue with those single service colleges without injecting into the military equation the need for too much jointery too early in the career of officer trainees. That is basically what that report is all about—bringing into a joint environment the three single service colleges much earlier than is the present situation.

The second point I would like to discuss briefly is in relation to staff colleges. As the right honourable gentleman has said—and I think I agree—the response from the department, certainly in the response document, was somewhat inadequate. In fact, a lot could be done in terms of the staff colleges. At the moment, the staff colleges—again for the benefit of 13 RCU—are: at HMAS
Penguin
at Balmoral, Sydney, for the navy; at Queenscliff, Victoria, for the army; and at RAAF Fairbairn, Canberra, for the air force.

I think we all agreed in the committee that there was room to manoeuvre in terms of a core curriculum for those three colleges, to bring them together much more than they are at the moment, and then to have some sort of single‐service training in conjunction with this core approach.

That has not been agreed by the government. It is one of the recommendations that did have a lot of validity and could have been done in the short term. I just hope that the two ministers for defence, in conjunction with the defence department bureaucracy, the commander of the defence force and the three chiefs of staff, are going to look more carefully at the situation of the staff colleges. I agree with Mr Sinclair that that particular one is disappointing. A lot could have been done in the short to medium term, albeit that there would have been budgetary implications. Those budgetary implications could have been programmed into what is a very extensive budget indeed.

I would like to talk briefly about the Australian Defence Force Academy. The report says that the present arrangements should be terminated and that we should go back to an undergraduate scheme utilising all the universities around Australia which, of course, was the previous course of action.

I disagree with that; it is not a fundamental disagreement, because the government's response also says that it will be kept under review. The reason that I say it is inappropriate at this point in time is that nobody who has graduated from the Defence Force Academy, to my knowledge, has yet achieved the rank of major. It is probably a little too early to do it. So whilst I do not oppose totally what is in the report in terms of a review of it, I do oppose the specifics of recommendation 14 that the Defence Force Academy arrangements should be terminated. I think that that will be reviewed in the coming years. I agree with Mr Sinclair that we should have an open mind about it, and that really is reflected in the government's response.

One specific point in relation to the cadet movement: I think all of us and the Australian nation need to understand the very parlous conditions and the very ad hoc arrangements under
which young men and women like this have to operate. It is very difficult for them to get basic uniforms and equipment, and whilst we do not want to get involved here this morning in the mechanics of the present rather vociferous public debate on firearm reform proposals, it is difficult for a lot of groups like 13 RCU to really feel that they are part of something leading up to a meaningful career if they do not have some of the basics. I want to take the opportunity to place on the
Hansard
record something that Bryce Rogers raised with me this morning. It is something that I have had raised with me by another officer commanding the Toowoomba Grammar School cadet unit only in the last 10 days as well.

The final point I want to make in this debate is to read into the
Hansard
record an extract from a letter that I received only in the last few days from one of the nation's most senior retired officers. It relates not specifically to this debate but to the role of defence. I take the opportunity to place this on the record. He said this:
It does seem to me that current defence thinking needs to be challenged in a number of areas, not least being how long can we really afford to continue with Jindalee—
that happens to be the over‐the‐horizon radar, which is the subject of some Auditor‐General's reports currently before the parliament.
Is large expenditure on a new joint headquarters really justified in our present strategic circumstances?
I would agree with that. I think command and control arrangements really have got out of hand and we need, as a government, particularly, to look at that. He continues:
Has the HQADF grown too large at the expense of the three Services' ability to provide their deep expertise on matters of policy?
I think maybe there is a modicum of truth in that, although we do need to press down the joint approach. Finally, he says:

From an industry point of view, when is Defence going to give more than lip service to the Government's policy of providing industry with much clearer strategic guidance and bringing industry into the planning process much earlier?

Those are important points to make in the context of a debate which is not only related to the officer corps. I agree with the right honourable gentleman that the `military after next' is a very catchy phrase; it is appropriate under the circumstances. It is important also to make mention of some of these points in a wider portfolio, a wider strategic viewpoint, because young people like those we have here today need to understand some of these things.

question.speaker: Latham, Mark, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 1 May 1996:

question.para:
(1) Further to the answer to question No. 985 (
Hansard
, 3 May 1994, page 136), will he bring up‐to‐date the estimated benefits to the business sector nationally resulting from local government authorities reaching best practice standards in development approval processes.
(2) How were the figures referred to in part (1) calculated.
(3) What measures will the government introduce to facilitate best practice.

answer.speaker: Smith, Warwick, MP

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para:
(1) Within my portfolio areas of responsibility there has been no update to the estimate provided to the House in 1994 (
Hansard
, 3 May 1994, question No. 985) on the benefits to the business sector resulting from local governments reaching best practice standards in the development approval processes.

(3) The Government has undertaken a number of projects to facilitate best practice including the continuation of the National Awards for Innovation. answer.speaker: Sharp, John, MP

question.speaker: Andren, Peter, MP

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 29 May 1996 :

question.para: (1) Has Australian Defence Industries (ADI) submitted a bid for the supply of Steyr rifles to the armed forces of Thailand; if so, what is (a) the status of the bid and (b) the Government's position on supplying the rifles.
(2) Is ADI's facility at Lithgow, NSW, vital to maintaining an Australian defence capability.
(3) Is it a fact that ADI Lithgow is able to supply tracks for tanks and armoured personnel carriers which are being purchased from the USA; if so, why are the tracks not being purchased from ADI.

answer.speaker: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(a) I have been informed that the bid is being considered by the Royal Thai Army.
(b) The Government supports the ADI bid.
(2) No, the future of the ADI Lithgow facility will depend on its commercial viability.

(3) ADI has been a supplier of tracks for the Army's armoured personnel carriers (APCs) since 1989. I am advised that negotiations are currently in progress between the Army and ADI for the supply of an upgraded track for APCs. As an interim measure only, the Army has placed a six month order with a US company for supply of tracks to ensure continuity of supply pending the outcome of negotiations with ADI.
ADI has not supplied tracks for tanks for several years, nor has it expressed an interest in doing so. The Army has never purchased tank tracks from the USA.
